rationale: The triple <http://example.org/x1> rdf:type <http://example.org/t1> can be inferred from the given information because ex:x1 is the subject of property ex:r2, which has ex:t1 specified as its domain.

The owl:sameAs predicate is reflexive, and any entity is always identical to itself. The triple <http://example.org/y1> owl:sameAs <http://example.org/y1> is stating that y1 is the same as itself, which is always true.

The owl:sameAs predicate is reflexive, meaning any entity is always the same as itself. Since both the subject and object of the triple are identical (<http://example.org/x1>), this triple is true by definition, regardless of any other information provided about x1.
The triple is true because y2 is the object of relation r2, and r2 has a range of t2. According to RDFS semantics, this implies that y2 is of type t2.

The owl:sameAs predicate is reflexive, and any entity is always identical to itself. The triple <http://example.org/y2> owl:sameAs <http://example.org/y2> is stating that y2 is the same as itself, which is always true.

The triple <http://example.org/y1> rdf:type <http://example.org/t2> can be inferred from the given information. Specifically, ex:y1 is the object of a triple with predicate ex:r2, and ex:r2 has a range of ex:t2. This allows us to conclude that ex:y1 must be of type ex:t2.

The functional property ex:r2 relates ex:x1 to both ex:y1 and ex:y2. Since a functional property can only relate a subject to one unique object, this implies that ex:y1 and ex:y2 must be the same entity. Therefore, the statement ex:y2 owl:sameAs ex:y1 is true.

The functional property ex:r2 relates ex:x1 to both ex:y1 and ex:y2. Since a functional property can only have one unique value for each instance, ex:y1 and ex:y2 must be the same, which is exactly what owl:sameAs expresses.
